It would be a back up device for my other tablet with cellular access when wifi not available.I ordered the Kindle Fire HD (KFHD) 8.9 4G/32gig tablet on October 26, 2012 and it was delivered on 11/29/2012, one day earlier than Amazon advised. The KFHD arrived by US POST! But it started somewhere in the USA handled by FedEx. The packaging was superb. Too bad you had to rip the package to get into the device, as it makes a beautiful box otherwise.The KFHD had enough power to launch BUT during the set up process, it does advise you to plug it in. **When I ordered this device, I was warned that it did not come with a charger. I don't know how people miss that advise. In Amazon's way, it tells you that people who purchase this item also bought a charger, screen protector, and a cover/case. I'm glad that a charger was not included. I have three chargers for my iPad and I can use these chargers to plug in the KFHD's cable. Good idea Amazon-->one less device to throw away or store somewhere.The set up process was really easy. The KFHD already recognized me!! And it stepped me through the process of connecting to my home WiFi. Right after that process completed, the KFHD stepped me through the process of signing up for the 250MG/12 month introductory 4GLTE AT&T; cellular data.  ***A lot of negative comments about this cellular data is unwarranted, IMHO. AT&T; is a reputable company, the set up process to access their network was very simple. Why people had problems filling out what is in essence an application form that consisted of Name, Address/City/State/Zipcode, email address and credit card is beyond me.I am speculating that since AT&T; has been the cellular provider in past iterations of the Kindle, adding other cellular data providers would probably require hardware changes as well. For example, AT&T; and Verizon do not use the same cellular technology. Giving a poor review to the KFHD because you cannot choose your cellular data provider is like going to a bread store and demanding to buy meat. For you iPad owners, we now have a choice of buying a branded AT&T; or Verizon or Sprint iPads. Amazon would need to do the same if they were inclined to spend time to negotiate similar deals with other providers.Now, onto the device itself. The screen resolution is really good. It almost compares to the Retina screen on the iPad (3/4th generation). I can see a difference between the KFHD screen and the iPad but if I didn't have the ability to compare it would be very difficult. The KFHD's home page is easy to navigate and to scroll through every thing I have accessed on it. I have to double tap on my iPad to do the same thing. I like having my iPad apps in folders, but I can grow to like the simplicity of the KFHD's presentation.I am a little bit puzzled about aquiring apps outside of Amazon. Apparently you have to go into settings to enable this function. And then you have to go to Google+ Play to get other apps not in the Amazon app store.Amazon's browser is different. You can access other websites but the speed of acquiring those websites seems a lot slower. But faster on the KFHD than an iPad. If you want to go backwards on the screen you are reading, the back button is on the side and not embedded in the window.There is a star icon that if you press it, gives you a list of favorite apps that you can launch without going to the home screen.The sound is certainly a lot richer than the monotone iPad. I watched a 15 minute segment of a movie on the KFHD, picture and sound was very realistic. I can get the same sense on my iPad but I have to plug in earphones to the iPad.The KFHD form factor, its size and weight, is easier to hold over a longer period of time than doing the same function on my iPad.In summary, the KFHD is a very good device to acquire and use Amazon Kindle products. It is certainly a lot more reasonably priced than comparable iPad products. The 4G cellular data is a bargain compared to the the US$14.95 250 mg per month AT&T; subscription on the iPad. I hope this 'introductory offer' will continue for as long as I own this device. The screen and stereo sound are attractive. I highly recommend it to anyone who wants a tablet to read books, watch TV/Movies, and browse websites. This has met all my requirements. I cannot rate it a five star device because there is no technology available that would merit such praise. This KFHD comes close.

Reviews.Title: Love most of it; dislike a couple of things
Reviews.Author: vergilius
Reviews.Content: This is my opinion of my Kindle Fire HD 8.9" 4G LTE tablet. I'm not really qualified to write a review.Love:*The display. Great HD.*The sound (I can hear the string basses at the beginning of "Das Reingold.")*The ease of navigating the Amazon world. I have Amazon Prime, which makes this device treat you like a friend. Yes, Amazon, you have made it very easy to buy stuff from you. Thank you. I'd do it anyway. If you don't have Prime, either get it or consider a Google Nexus 7 or 10 instead.*GPS and 4g. 4G is why I got this instead of a Nexus 10. ATT 4G works well here in Monroe, Michigan. GPS means that Google Maps and Back Country Navigator also work well.*The speed. It's fast.Like:*I can side load most of my apps from the Google market (but not all, unfortunately). Yeah, Google is a competitor with Amazon, so I get why I have to load them that way. It's just a bit irritating.*The battery life. Pretty good.Don't care:*Only has a front camera. Tablets are way too bulky for taking pictures. I'll just take them with my Droid Bionic and send them to my tablet for viewing and processing.Hate:The carousel. Lose it Amazon. It's extraordinarily irritating, sort of like having a cowlick in my hair that will never stay down. I want to customize a number of home screens, like my wife does on her Galaxy Tab 7.What to know:It's basically a Kindle. You know how you said when you got your first Kindle, "Gee, this is neat. Wouldn't it be great if they did it in color and you could watch videos, too?" Well, that's what Amazon has done in a superb manner.OK. Here's an update that I have to post:IF YOU USE FACEBOOK A LOT, DON'T GET A KINDLE FIRE HD. There is a major issue which at this time seems unresolved.  The Kindle Fire HD will only allow a few recent news feeds to be displayed (like maybe 15 to 20).  The last few will be displayed shaded in blue and you can't load any more of them.  So if you want to scroll down to something that you saw an hour or so ago, forget it.  The only work around that I found was to change the user agent to "desktop" instead of "android" in settings, but that makes some posts with pictures too big to view. One suggestion from an Amazon moderator on the Kindle Fire User's Forum was for us users to contact Facebook and make them aware of the problem.  It seems to me that Amazon ought to be the one to take such an initiative, since it is Amazon's modification of the Android platform that has probably caused the problem.UPDATE OF UPDATE (2/2012): The Facebook issue is resolved in the both the Facebook App and the Facebook site within Dolphin Browser on my Kindle HD.  I'm not sure who took care of the problem, but thanks!

Reviews.Title: A short review
Reviews.Author: Amazon Customer "Tech is Good!"
Reviews.Content: Ok, my wife has an Ipad2, I have a Kindle Touch and a Kindle Fire(original)..so I think I can make good comparisons.  You just want to read?  Get the Kindle Paperwhite...it is like the Kindle Touch only even better(my daughter has the PaperWhite).  Can't beat the plain e-ink Kindles for just reading. I will not be giving up my trusty Kindle Touch for when I only need a reader.But for multiple uses?? Ok, the new Kindle 8.9 has me impressed!  The older plain Fire was just fine for light reading,checking email, and using apps(gaming).  But although adequate for those purposes, it was lousy for any serious websurfing...screen just too small (just like my cell phone works for the web, but not well).  Screen on the new Kindle 8.9..... just perfect!!  Goldilocks syndrome, not too small, not too large, just right!  Ipad2 is nice, but just a little too big and too heavy.Oh, I'm guessing it goes without saying that I'm fond of the Amazon ecosystem.  And I don't have to install that memory hog ITunes!!!Amazon has a winner here....it is nice enough that I'm writing this review on it!!In short, nice unit, after 6 hours with it, I'm very happy with my purchase.  If battery life is better than the original Fire, I'll be ecstatic!!Edit: Had the unit for several days, and am happier than ever.  Unit is faster than my Original Fire, and really almost the ideal size for using the web, email, etc.  Needs a case, which I am ordering,but otherwise size, speed, and usability are excellent.  My Ipad envy is gone. No need to spend $200 more, there just isn't that much that the Ipad can do that this can't (at least for me).  As always, Amazon Prime makes getting content ridiculously easy (maybe too easy sometimes!)

Reviews.Title: Amazon..  please, please, please
Reviews.Author: Shu
Reviews.Content: please make every poster click an agreement that..-they understand that Adobe not longer provides Flash for mobile devices which means the Kindle Fire HD's does not have Flash.-that the unit does not come with a charger as clearly stated in the product description.-that they understand that the unit doesn't come with a printed user guide.-if they have a problem connecting to their WiFi network or getting slow response downing loading, youtube, etc.. it's the network not the  device.-that they actually have read the production description before complaining about what the product won't do.-forgot, they should actually own and have used the device and not complain about why they didn't buy it.-if the box was crushed, dirty, etc..  they have a shipper problem not a Amazon/device problem.######################my background..-62, retired, 40 years if IT background. mainframe sna networking, tcpip networking via about every switch Cisco has ever made, last 5 or 6 years spent specializing in Cisco wireless networking.my review of the product.-arrived Monday, properly packaged, already registered to me with about 50% battery charge.-never owned a tablet or android device before but seemed fairly easy to get setup.-I downloaded and install Flash and Dolphin from watching Mr Gadget on youtube, might have taken 5 minutes.-no problems with multiple forums, youtube, pandora, nbc, cbs, pbs, usatoday, drudge, etc.. Gmail took under 5 minutes to setup.-the BT streams directly to my hearing aid streamer which streams directly into my hearing aids in stereo. the BT turns on and off automatically when going to youtube or pandora, etc.-I have added an app for WiFi and Battery.-downloaded sample books.-uploaded music to the cloud and pulled it back down to the kindle.-I have streamed several movies via the kindle to my 55 inch Samsung TV.-I can find absolutely nothing that doesn't work as designed on the kindle or works slowly.- upgrading the product to 5 stars as I can find no reason not to.btw, I ordered the charger and a stylus (which works better than my fat fingers) both were the the box with the Kindle.

Reviews.Title: Very Disappointed
Reviews.Author: Viki
Reviews.Content: I saved for a year to buy this and am VERY disappointed.  The first one they shipped me wouldn't stay on longer than 30 seconed.  The second wouldn't connect to WI-FI until I purchased a new wireless modem at my house.  My old Kindle (one of the earlier versions) connects anywhere, but this one will only work within 12 feet of my modem at home.  $300 down the drain.  So disappointed.

Reviews.Title: A thing of beauty is a joy forever!
Reviews.Author: Nancy Parker "N. Parker"
Reviews.Content: This won't be a fact-filled review listing all the capabilities of the Kindle Fire HD 8.9". Many have done that already extremely well.  This is purely subjective, expressing my appreciation for wonderful technology.I am completely familiar with the Fire HD, having purchased the 7” when it first launched.  I returned it because it was just too small.  I know millions love that small form factor ... not me.THIS one is perfection.  Not enough hyperboles to express how gorgeous the display is, how full and rich the sound, how smoothly movies play, how wonderful reading a book is, and most importantly for me, how perfect the size is.  It is so thin and light and is a delight to hold.  Even the carousel, which I really don't like, seems better on the 8.9" :).  It will be perfect to take in my purse!I truly love this device and that is coming from an iPad 3 owner.  Highly highly recommend!

Reviews.Title: Love it!
Reviews.Author: js
Reviews.Content: I love reading all these initial reviews, some are quite humorous, some are WAY too long. Mine to the point.First all the people complaining about an instruction manual, we live in a digital age... look under help menu. This tablet is not that complicated.Next, no charger included.. ok yea they could have included a charger... but wait for it... wait for it... if you are an iphone user, simply unplug the usb iphone charger and put in place the kindle usb cord and plug it in.. problem solved.Next problem... no adobe flash... here's a news flash.. not amazon's fault.. try writing adobe as they are the ones that said no more adobe flash on android products.Next... It is not a computer, or a laptop... don't expect it to be.Ok, i have only seen 2 valid, you can't get around complaints as of November 16th, no zagg skin to fit the 8.9, nor no otterbox or gumdrop case for those that prefer the heavy duty case... that should have been available when the 8.9 was released... but it probably will in the future. Go to Best Buy, get a 9"zagg and it will fit, not great, but it will do for now until zagg comes out with one.To sum it up I love it!, its cheaper than Ipad, touchscreen is nice, power button being located next to the volume button is nice.

Reviews.Title: Good concept, so-so execution. Browser is the WORST!
Reviews.Author: onehundredyearsold
Reviews.Content: I purchased the fire 8.9 as an entertainment system. I wasn't upset at all about being "locked in" to buying content from Amazon, I'd be doing that anyway. Can't beat Amazon for selection or service.The sound and picture are superb. Crisp picture and surprisingly good (almost) surround sound. Watching movies from Amazon is outstanding.Love reading my books on it. Some books should be paper but for most books the Kindle gives more features than paper ever can. It is nice to be able to get word definitions while still on the page you're reading. I like the x-ray feature too.Battery life is fabulous. I can use it for hours and hours between recharges. Internet connection is fast and reliable. The size is good for holding to read or watching shows. It is not so heavy that one tires of holding it too soon.However, not all the features of the fire are equally a success.The Silk browser is poor in features,functionality and performance. Silk tends to crash at least hourly (frequently more often). It's constantly saying whatever page I'm on has stopped responding and would I like the page restored. How could the developers have missed that? Why is there no word about an intent to remedy this constant failure of a basic web browser. Since I bought this for entertainment, I'm feeling less entertained and more annoyed.The typing feature is glitchy.  It frequently misses the first letter typed while compensating you for this problem by giving you double of the next letter you type. Space bar is inexplicably flaky.Some of the applications I've purchased though they were listed as compatible, crash.For this being their flagship Kindle product they should be ashamed to have let this be distributed with flaws that could have been fixed. Now that it is out I'm afraid they will not feel an obligation to improve the interface and functionality but instead will play hot potato, with the consumers holding their potato Kindles. Perhaps they should have named it the Kindle Crash.But possibly I am wrong and Amazon is working to improve it's product. I do have to say I have always received excellent service from Amazon and perhaps it will carry over to the Kindle Fire as well.Update May 29,2013No significant updates to resolve issues. So tired of having to make compromises, especially with the browser. I almost feel like they realize it's beyond repair. I will be buying a different tablet,probably an iPad. Definitely NOT a Kindle anything ever again.

Reviews.Title: Excellent tablet!!  BEAUTIFUL HD screen, great sound, 'snappy' processing!
Reviews.Author: Matthew J. Haslett "Kindle lover!"
Reviews.Content: I am a long time lover of all things Kindle, just to put that out there.  So yes, perhaps I am a bit biased due to having an extensive Kindle library, but nonetheless, I can say with as much objectivity as I can muster: this is a wonderful device that I would not hesitate recommending to someone.  And please know, I've been around for a few years now and I have learned to *NOT* recommend things to people, or at least some people, because inevitably something will go wrong and *YOU* will now become the focus of their displeasure.  So, for me to recommend this is a definite leap of faith. :)There are plenty of excellent in-depth reviews so I will not rehash them.  Suffice it to say that Amazon did a great job with this device and I am more than pleased with it.The screen is beautiful, the sound is very nice and loud, it performs very well, and the interface is much improved over the previous generation Fire, which we also owned and liked.  This is truly much closer to the iPad in terms of functionality and performance in my opinion.  And once you factor in pricing?  I have no idea what, after reading up on the iPad, what it could possibly do to warrant the price premium, I honestly don't.  And please don't think that I'm just simply bashing Apple, because we own various iPod variants and an iPhone 5.  Android devices do outnumber Apple devices in our house, but Apple is still represented and I have to say, the new Kindle Fire HD 8.9 is a definite winner.  If we had the resources there'd be one under the xmas tree of all of our relatives this year. :)To quickly address reading (what Kindle was originally all about!!) I still prefer an e-ink version to read on, and currently I'm using the Kindle Paperwhite and I absolutely love the screen, it is simply amazing.  The light is there when you need/want it and it is a joy to read on, no eye fatigue (at least no more than reading a paper book).  Reading on the Kindle Fire is nice though, the dictionary is exceptionally quick and the responsiveness of the Fire will always be quicker than that of its e-ink siblings, but that's just the nature of the involved technology, not a knock to e-ink, just a kudos to the Fire for being a fast device.  It is definitely nice to read on and I have, all I'm saying is that for lengthy periods of reading I prefer the e-ink, but there's nothing wrong with the experience on a Fire.And just to quickly address the griping about a charger not being included with the device: Amazon is leading the way with this.  How many devices do you own that use a micro-USB charger?  Quite a few I'd imagine.  Why on earth should Amazon add to the per-unit cost by including something that isn't 'truly' necessary nowadays?  I'm very happy to pay a little bit less for something than to have yet another charger laying around.  Yes, it does charge faster with a somewhat non-traditional charging rate of 1.8A, but still, I am all for overall reduced costs and a 'greener' product.  And I think that they make it quite clear that the charger is not included, so for those that complain about it, well, they probably complain about a lot of stuff in life if they pay that little attention to things - everything is everyone else's fault, not theirs, lol.Good luck and please, if you're thinking about it, take the plunge, you'll love your device.

Reviews.Title: Disappointed- Don't buy if you have large PDF format books
Reviews.Author: Nick S "Nick S"
Reviews.Content: Cons:I'm a medical doctor, and I bought the Kindle Fire because I was planning on using it to download my PDF format medical books. Although I am able to view the books, I'm unable to search or highlight the books. It's pointless to have a 500-1000 page reference that you can't search. The only way to get these options is to email the file to an Amazon email that they create for you. It will convert the file to the Kindle format for an outrageous fee per Megabit (~$.99) if it is under 50MB. If its more than 50MB you're shit out of luck.I have literally spent the whole day and night, researching this and talking to customer service by email and on the phone just to end up feeling frustrated and disappointed. I had to explain the same thing 3-5 times over to the customer service rep, there was some kind of language barrier with this foreign based help I received.I've wasted my time and money on this device for the purpose I bought it for. The whole thing is set up to keep pumping money into Amazon by forcing you to pay money for every little thing.They want you to buy a yearly subscription to Amazon Prime and then they say you get to watch free movies, get to share books, and get free two day shipping...how is it free if you're paying a yearly subscription???Also, I initially had problems with the Netflix and Pandora apps. It said they were downloaded but they didn't show up in my Apps folder. So I tried re-downloading them and it wouldn't let me because it said they were already downloaded. I emailed customer service multiple times giving them the specifics of my problem and they kept sending me the same generic email that didn't help at all.This device would be nice if you were only planning and buying everything you downloaded through Amazon. Its not as compatible with other document formats as it says it is.PROS:Nice screen and speakers along with fast WiFi.

Reviews.Title: Very disappointed - Loved 7" - Where to start with problems of 8.9"
Reviews.Author: lady_koenig
Reviews.Content: I loved the Kindle Fire 7" and was very excited to receive my 8.9" model. I am so disappointed I could cry.-) The battery will not hold a charge - one hour Max. I need to sit where there is an electrical outlet so I can plug in. It was plugged in overnight and did not fully charge.-) With the 7" I could scroll through dozens and dozens of posts on Facebook. With the 8.9" it will load what you first see on the screen, if you try to scroll you get the little circular icon that just continues to search. I have waited for 15 minutes and it never goes further even though I have 5 bars on the internet strength. By then the battery is drained from constant search. I give up and get out the 7" Fire.-) Touch screen is unresponsive. I have to keep an eye on what I type - I have 2 problems there. First, when I type many times the letters do not appear as typed and I may have to hit the key several times before the letter will appear. Second, The space bar when typing does not put in spaces. I will look up at screen and see just a mass of letters. I will have to scan the typed mass and attempt to put the curser at the appropriate place and hit the space bar until a space is added.I had read the reviews and felt the 8.9" had all the features and size I wanted. I come to the conculsion that I just got a lemon and will be returning it and looking at another brand of tablet. With this sad piece of electronics Amazon has lost one customer. How could they have gone from such a nice tablet as the 7" is to a piece of junk that I received in this 8.9" model? HD is fine if you just want to read your e-mail or view photos but that is not what I wanted this tablet for. I was hoping to get what it appears that most of reviews received. That is not what I received. I am taking my 7" Fire off the eBay listing and using it until I can get a better tablet at my local electronic store.I would not recommend this tablet to anybody. I am typing this review on my laptop since typing is one thing I can not do with the 8.9" tablet.

Reviews.Title: Very nice indeed, and a worthy upgrade to the first Fire
Reviews.Author: mbw
Reviews.Content: Of course a very early review, I've had my 32GB Fire HD (FHD) less than 24 hours, but what a difference over my Kindle Fire!Some of the pros:-the size is just right-the borders are big enough to hold onto without activating something on the screen-the color and resolution are stunning-the speed is an order of magnitude better than the Fire-connectivity is flawless to my wifi node-sound is actually 'stereo like' (from the front only) but more realistic than the older Fire, if still on the hollow side.In reality, this pad is better than my computer at work when it comes to streaming video like IMDb, YouTube, or Amazon Prime videos, (at the end of a long day when the work's done :). There are just no breaks or pauses.Another thing I've noticed is that this FHD model doesn't 'hang' like the older Fire did between tasks or websites. The new processor must have fixed these bugs.The interface is only slightly different from the original Fire and probably won't take me more than a couple hours to get used to. The scrolling images seem to have a bit more flare on the larger screen, but I've always prefered them over other interfaces like my daughters Nook.  I've noticed a star for accessing favorites in the lower right hand corner of the screen which I find very handy.  And the device tools are now a pull down....ok, that works.  Please Note!  If you buy this with 'Special Offers', you are forced to endure advertisements when you first turn it on, but it's $15 lower in price over a similar unit without 'Special Offers'.  Wow did I get tired of those ads real quick.  Not to worry....I was able to turn them off.....by paying the extra $15 difference in price! (you can do this after registration).I have played around a little with the built in camera, but from what I've seen, the resolution is low.  Skype is a nice feature but I haven't had an opportunity to try it out.So in short, they seem to have fixed all the shortcomings I found in the first standard Fire, improved the useability alot, and added some interesting features. I find this pad much more pleasurable to use and a worthy upgrade. I've handed my Fire over to someone non-techy but very near and dear and she is very happy...I'm mean, she got it for free so why wouldn't she be?  Which raises a point; the register and deregister process was a breeze. All my content transfered right over, (with the exception of some low-def game apps which I don't miss). If you want help, pls comment. I'd be happy to walk you through it.This case Amazon Kindle Fire HD 8.9" Standing Leather Case, Onyx Black (will only fit Kindle Fire HD 8.9") also comes highly recommended though on the expensive side, (please see my review).

Reviews.Title: Kindle Fire HD 8.9
Reviews.Author: biker boy 66 "biker boy"
Reviews.Content: First let me state that I am no expert on Tablets,I don't know anything about all of the technical details that I read on some of the reviews ,I have better things to do than play with my toys all day, and nitpick this tablet to death , but I think that the Kindle Fire HD 8.9 is AWSOME, it does everything that I ask it to do and more, picture is perfect, set up was easy. I LOVE IT. For the money , I don't think you can get a better deal on a Tablet, than this Kindle Fire HD 8.9. Thank you for reading my review.

Reviews.Title: Exactly what I needed
Reviews.Author: L. Hill
Reviews.Content: This larger Fire is exactly what I was looking for.  It fulfills ALL the needs I had for a tablet device - by which I am saying, make sure you KNOW what you need!I purchased the Gen1 Fire last year about a day after it was released.  I have used that one for a multitude of tasks - reading, watching video content, staying connected to email (and replying, but not generating new emails), and most of all as a "replacement" for paper documents I generated for use in teaching and preaching.  This was the MAIN use of my Gen1 Fire...but the screen was just too small.Thus - when the 8.9" was released, I ordered within 5 minutes of it posting on Amazon!  Wasn't going to wait this time - went with one day shipping too!  Then the wait...and the early receipt - that rocked!  I received my new Fire (hence named Dad's Bonfire to differentiate from the Gen1) about a week earlier than I anticipated, and immediately put it to work!  It was exactly as I expected - no disappointments.- Large, clear screen - allows me to create documents on desktop in 12point type, on a modified page (9.5" x 5.5" custom page size) that fits the width of the screen perfectly.  I save these documents in PDF format to "fix" the pages and limit reformatting.  At 12point, with this size screen, my lessons and sermons are perfectly sized to see from a lecturn or pulpit as I teach.- Apps - as I am not into a lot of games (ok...Angry Birds...who isn't) - the apps I already had for the Gen1 also worked on my Bonfire.  The "paid" apps (those I didn't grab for free in the past year) all transported as well - Calengoo, Evernote, Whiteboard, EasyPrint, Pulse, K-9 Mail, OfficesuitePro, Sketchbook Mobile, Proclaim Remote, Logos - all worked with no modifications on the new Bonfire.  Because the 8.9" uses a modified Android 4.1, most open even more functionality.- Carousel - still not a fan...I actually liked the "Favorites Bookshelf" from the Gen 1 better.  However, the carousel is smoother now, and more reactive than on the Gen1.  I have not had the problem of earlier reviewers of the carousel "populating" with everything.  I am not really a fan of how Favorites are now handled on the 8.9" - it is as if they are pushing you to use the carousel...it is a neat idea, but not really for me.- Sound - have to say...wow!  Compared to other "fruit" models - the dual speaker setup on the Fire is much superior.- HDMI out - I have streamed Amazon content from the Fire to my big screen tv...very nice.- Web - one area that still needs work.  I am not a fan of the Silk browser...am looking at moving to a side-loaded app...no matter what they say, it is slower than others, and seems to push you towards what THEY want...limited ability to customize the "starter" page - you get your most visited, then two rows - trending now, and selected sites - both selected, apparently, by Amazon...not for me.- Books - there are some really cool options now - like 2 column reading, x-ray, so on.  The pages are not as "bright" white as the Gen1 - which at first I didn't like, but now realize it is actually easier to read on!  There is even a "shadow" where the crease of the book pages would be - it looks like a "real" book!- Auto-Brightness - is outstanding.  I no longer find myself adjusting for reading in bed vs. reading at office vs. using outdoors.  Used for first time yesterday outside (not in direct sunlight, of courst) - and found I had no problem seeing the document I was speaking from.  Outstanding...- Dual-channel - very nice, as I am now using the 5G side of my router, slowing the demand on the 2.4 side for all the other devices at home!- Colors, Resolution, Screen - absolutely beautiful!  What more to say!Folks - for this price - there is nothing out there that does what I WANT to do.  I looked at the fruit - too expensive, especially when you consider the apps I would need.  Nexus - didn't handle documents with the ease that Amazon/Send to Kindle/Fire does!  I have installed the free app from Amazon on all my desktops, which gives you the "Send to Kindle" option...sure makes it easy to get a document to my Bonfire!  Two clicks on the document, and zap - there it is on the carousel!  I do not "create" much on my Fire - that is what desktops and laptops are for...this is my "consumption" device...teaching, preaching, reading, studying, checking email, so on - which is what I would use any tablet for...and the larger format of this Fire is OUTSTANDING for this.  For the money saved vs. other tablets - I have purchased a 7" Fire for my daughter for Christmas...tell me another place you can get the large size and the mini size for these prices!!!Back to beginning - make sure you know what YOU WANT to do with a tablet - and let that drive your decision.  This Fire does ALL I want...and more!

Reviews.Title: The best tablet for entertainment / consumption for the price
Reviews.Author: MamaBear
Reviews.Content: I received the 9" model today and absolutely love it. Here's a brief review of this product for the community to hopefully better assist people with making their purchase decision.A little background about my tablet experienceCurrently owned:Mobile device - AndroidTablet device - MS Surface windows RT, Kindle Fire HD 7"Ipad 3 - (wife's)This tablet size and weight surprisingly surpassed my expectation. The seer hardward looks and feels Quality. I love every detail amazon spent on engineering this: speakers and hd screen and obviously the price is unbelievably cheap.After having the Surface and Ipad experience, I felt like I should just sell those device and can have enough money to buy a Fire for everyone in my family. There is absolutely no reason why I shouldn't.

Reviews.Title: Expected More...
Reviews.Author: Rick
Reviews.Content: I have owned a few Android tablets and when I was looking to upgrade from my Samsung Galaxy Tab 2 10.1 to a smaller / faster tablet, I was torn between the Samsung Galaxy Tab 3 8.0 and the Kindle Fire HD 8.9. I finally went with the Fire based mainly on what appeared to be some impressive features for the price as well as the ability to utilize my Amazon Prime membership with the device (The Galaxy Tabs are not supported for some odd reason, yet the Ipads are?).Since there are thousands of reviews, I'm just going to give my TOP 5 pros and cons.The pros so far:1) Setup couldn't have been easier! I love how they had much of the tablet configured with my Prime movies and all my purchased music available, etc. Really well done!2) The tablet feels good in my hand and I love the "in between" size of 8.9" vs. the 10" I was used to and the 7" which I tried and was way too small for me.3) The screen is very nice and it has a surprisingly good resolution for watching movies. I will say it's great to finally have a tablet where I can utilize my prime membership.4) The app store has a good selection and downloading is even easier than the Google Play store. Also, it's nice to be able to make a subtle adjustment to the settings on the device so I can still download apps not available on the Amazon store. Amazon does need to beef up their selection of apps though.5) I think the speakers are pretty darn impressive! You can hear the difference between other tablets, it's that striking!The cons so far:1) I know others have said this ad nauseum, but paying extra for a charger that EVERY OTHER manufacturer includes just left a very bad taste in my mouth. I would have preferred they increased the price of the tablet by $10 or $15 bucks if they really couldn't afford to include it for the price they charge.2) Although I'm starting to get used to it (out of necessity), I'm not a fan of the carousel at all. I guess I understand why Amazon decided on a modified Android OS, but it would be nice if there was an option to revert back to the traditional Android look as it is far more user friendly than what Amazon has created. Frankly, it's making me question whether I made the right decision to purchase the Fire.2) Maybe it's just me, but the Amazon web browser is terrible! I don't know if I've seen pages load so slowly since I had an old 486 computer in the 90's! And I have a terrific internet connection at home with a blazing fast router, so I'm pretty sure it's not me. But the Amazon browser showed choppy displays, etc. On some pages, I couldn't even scroll down for 30 seconds to a minute until it loaded. Navigation wasn't good and it's not nearly as customizable as other browsers. Thank goodness I was able to add a third party browser which is working very well (fast and clear, etc.). I know I won't ever use the Amazon browser again unless they have a significant update which corrects all the performance issues.3) As has been stated by most, the power and volume buttons on the side are so flush to the device that they're extremely hard to access. Raising them just a hair would have made a big difference.4) The lack of a micro SD slot is a big miss and again makes me wonder if I made the right decision. I guess I was more than a little surprised at how much space Amazon's OS took up out of the 16GB. I would have gone for the 32GB but for some reason it was not eligible for the student discount, which didn't make much sense to me. On the plus side, I do like that all my Amazon media is stored on the cloud and easily accessible and I have a dropbox account for the rest, but there are times you want to store more on the actual device. And the way the Fire is setup, 16GB doesn't provide much flexibility at all.5) I was very surprised at how poorly downloaded magazines looked on this device. I have a PC World subscription and since they went all digital this past month, the only way for me to read the magazine is by downloading. I would have expected the Fire to be extremely adept at this, but it was quite the contrary. My old Galaxy Tab 2.0 had more clarity and smoother action from page to page. The Fire was extremely choppy and did not display the sharpest picture. In fact, when turning pages the images would distort for at least 5 to 10 seconds on the Fire where that never happened on my other tablets.In conclusion, I really WANT to like the Fire more than I do. Without an Android based option to view Amazon Prime content and all the options which should make this a "best in class" device, the execution of several key tablet essentials is inconsistent at best. Maybe there are explanations to the issues I've discovered that Amazon could answer but as of now, I'm not sure as to whether I'll keep this after the 30 day return option period.

Reviews.Title: sending Samsung note 10.1 back..will never give up my Kindle Fire 8.9 HD- THE BEST TABLET OUT THERE
Reviews.Author: Kindle Customer "BBB"
Reviews.Content: Plus Amazon has THE BEST customer service out there...and that can be equally as important as the quality of the device. We wont repeat whats been said other than if you're looking for the BEST picture & sound quality for movies...Netflix....Huluplus...HBOGO etc. reading...web surfing and more...this is far better than Samsungs 10.1 note and even our ipad!!! If/when Amazon ever decides to do a 10.1 or larger tablet...they'll blow EVERYONE including Apple, out of the water! This is an Exceptional product.... you won't regret purchasing!!

Reviews.Title: Love it, Love it, Love it!!!!!
Reviews.Author: camping queen
Reviews.Content: After hours of research I decided that this was the device for me.Than the long and some what impatient wait for this to arrive, I have to say that I am very happy.I do not seem to have a problem with the power button, once I found it, which did take a minute, I havenot had a problem since than.Set up was very easy and the device walks you right through it.Books look great on this device.  I do have to turn down the brightness to read, my eyes are somewhat light sensitive, other that that they are very crisp and clean looking.  I could see not havinga way to organize your books in the future being a pain, but at this time I don't have that many booksin my library.There are more than enough apps for me.  Haven't run across one that I am missing at thistime.My email is not compatible with this device, but I really don't care.  I prefer to go to my emailthrough the web anyway, which I am able to do with no issues using silk.I have watched tv shows available through my amazon prime account and they have been veryclear and the sound has been great. Netflix was a little glitchey at first, but than it cleared itself up,I only used it for a few minutes to test out the app, so I am not sure how it would work for a longperiod of time.I have surfed the web with silk almost everyday.  I have not run into any issues.The keyboard does not give me any problems, if you are used to using an iphone or smartphonekeyboard you should be fine.  If not, it will take a little time to get used to.Just to give people an idea about this kindle,  I do not feel that it will ever replace my laptop, nor doI want it to. I have a macbook that I paid a lot of money for so why would I want it to.I have an iphone as well, which I enjoy using and am comfortable with, therefore if there are apps Iwant from apple I can get them on my iphone.  I also use my iphone for music so I at this time I don't see theneed to have my music on my kindle, that may change or it may not.I bought the prowerfast charger, it does what it is supposed to do, no issues there either.Over all if you are looking for an ereader that has a few more bells and whistles, this is a great choice.If you are looking for a machine to do everything a computer does, this is not it.  I would recommend youlook into some of the newer computers coming out.

Reviews.Title: Sleek, Thinner, Tablet
Reviews.Author: prisrob "pris,"
Reviews.Content: I have the first generation kindle, a Kindle Fire and now the Kindle Fire HD 8.9 16 GB. I pre-ordered this Kindle the day it was announced in September. I was pleased to receive my new Kindle at least two weeks earlier than advertised.The Kindle arrived in the same black packaging as the Kindle Fire. Easy to open with the side zip. Once out of it's box, the Kindle is sleek, thinner than the i-Pad. It is the same height. Simple directions are found in a side pocket of the inner packaging.The buttons are placed along the upper right side, horizontally. They are flush to the tablet, and for some these buttons seem to be more difficult to find.  Turn the Fire on, swipe the lock key, the tablet asks for your Wi-Fi password, you select your time zone and confirm your account. Very easy compared to many other tablets. Now, the real experience begins. Your apps have been automatically configured from other kindles. There is an amazing array of other apps to choose from. The Kindle brings you through the entire process. You click on next to go from one page to the next in the setup process.One of the best improvements, among many is email. Very easy to set up, the email is crisp and clear.  The Fire HD 8.9 is the version to get. Its larger, higher-resolution screen better facilitates Amazon's still-new Kindle Fire interface, and its faster processor makes for a much smoother and zippier experience.. The tablet's availability in a Wi-Fi-only version ($299 for 16GB, $369 for 32GB) and a 4G LTE Wireless version $499 for 32GB, $599 for 64GB, is superb. Speakers are mounted on either side and the sound is so much better.Streaming films from Netflix or Amazon Prime is the way to go. Crisp, clear vision and the HD sound!  Moving from one app to another is very fast. I purchased 'Best 100 Kindle Fire HD Apps' as suggested by another reviewer, and it is an excellent source. For $.99, a great deal of information is available.So far, I have been disappointed with the selection of Kindle Fire HD covers, expensive. I will do more research to find one that is perfect for me.I am extremely pleased with this Kindle Fire HD 8.9 tablet. It has everything I have wanted in a tablet with faster service and Amazon's experience. The lack of a specific charger is not a problem, I have several I can use. I have been listening to Mumford and Sons while writing this review, and the sound is just superb!Highly Recommended. prisrob 11-20-12Amazon Kindle PowerFast for Accelerated Charging (not included with device, for use with the new Kindle Fire or Kindle Fire HD models)

Reviews.Title: Vast Improvement
Reviews.Author: Mbail
Reviews.Content: Very impressed with my new Kindle Fire HD 8.9.  I have the original Kindle Fire and have been happy with it, but the new version addresses most of my gripes with the previous version.  First and foremost, storage; I purchased the 32 Gb version and it was well worth the extra money.  I have download a couple audio books, a music playlist with about 50 songs, all of my magazines, a few books and most of my apps and have about 23 Gb left.  Doesn't sound like a lot, but I was constantly managing the space on my original Kindle Fire and would have never downloaded music or audiobooks, it just took too much space.  The gmail integration is much improved.  I can move e-mails to my gmail folders with the native app and it also syncs to my contacts and gmail calendar.  Ahh, so much nicer.  There is more customization available such as the ability to set the brightness to auto, turn off the last web page showing on the carousel, turn on notifications for applications, and turn off Amazon Home recommendations.  Amazon has learned there lesson well.  Give us an interface that is easy to use, but give us some customization to make it pretty.  The HD screen is very nice.  I plugged the device into my flat screen and the picture and sound were good.  Bluetooth was easy to use and worked with my bluetooth headphones, including forwarding through songs.In fact, I would have rated this five stars if not for the Silk browser.  Don't get me wrong, it gets the job done, but it crashes on the more intesive websites (esp. Adobe).  Also, if Amazon is driving us to the cloud, why can I not store my bookmarks there?  I have every confidence Amazon will get it right with Silk, but I can't give it five stars since one of the main reason I have a tablet is a bit buggy.

Reviews.Title: Sorely disappointed
Reviews.Author: Donald Atkinson
Reviews.Content: I love Amazon, and I love my e-Ink Kindles so I had high hopes for the Kindle Fire HD 8.9" and honestly I didn't think it was that bad for the first couple of weeks.  I've had it for about 2 months now and the only way to describe my feeling toward it at this point is buyer's remorse.  I had bought this as a replacement for my original iPad which is no longer supported and it has gotten quite sluggish at pretty much everything.  Initial impressions were good--but it is no iPad--it was also half the cost.  There were annoyances like it just freezing up completely for 30 seconds at a time before resuming what it was doing like nothing happened, but I figured I could live with it for at least a year despite those and it wouldn't have cost me any more than my iPad cost me since I got less than three years worth of useful life out of it.  BUT, two months in I am now getting about 10 minutes worth of use out of a complete charge!  Let me say that again in case you weren't paying attention...10 MINUTES USE FROM A COMPLETE CHARGE!!!  With a full charge I play about 10-20 minutes of Simpsons Tapped out on it (which doesn't take the battery meter down very much) and then leave it until the next day when I get home from work and it ALWAYS says that the battery is dead.  I don't have any notifications turned on so I don't know what it is doing all day that drains the battery--but at this point it is nothing more than a $400 paperweight--yes, I bought the ridiculously expensive cover too.I will unequivocally state that I'd pay twice as much for an iPad.EDIT:So after letting this sit for a day I realized that it wasn't much more than venting and didn't really provide much useful information.  So, here is something a little more useful to add.The display is excellent, though the touch sensor is not the greatest--does not seem to be very accurate or sensitive and suffers from the general lag of the system.  The system is a bit slow to respond to input, but seems to run most things pretty quickly.  I'm not sure what might cause this other than the overhead of Android.Many complain about the lack of the Google Play store, but I don't really see this as that big an issue.  You can side load anything that you download from Google Play on another Android device--it is just not nearly as convenient.The placement of the power button is annoying--I'm constantly accidentally turning it on or turning it off.  (Or at least I did when I was using it more.)Web browsing is one of the major things I had planned on using it for.  Web browsing is not a joy.  I don't remember specifics but after about a week I gave up on it for that purpose and went back to my iPad.One thing that I found extremely annoying is when I had the notifications turned on it would take me to the Amazon App Store when I told it to clear the notifications.  I'd think that would only happen if I tapped on a specific notification that was an advertisement.I also purchased the HDMI cable for it and was disappointed in the output of it.  It wasn't horrible, but not something I would use without a specific need to.The micro-USB charging port is HORRIBLE!  If you don't get the cable plugged in just right it will not charge at all--and it makes the device extremely hot to boot.  Always check to make sure you have a charging indicator when you plug in the cable.The extremely expensive case also disappointed me.  It does not fit tight enough and I've accidentally pulled it off several times when I've picked it up by the corner.  It also exacerbates the issue with the placement of the power button.I don't use my tablets to watch movies but when I tried that it seemed to work without problems.  I also don't use them to listen to music and I'm pretty sure I didn't even try that so while the sound is pretty good on the things I've used it for I can't really say how it might be for things that are more sound demanding.  Another thing I don't use it for is reading books--I have an e-Ink Kindle for that.  And I've never used the camera on it.One thing that I find annoying about Android in general is the lack of quality apps available.  Sure, the big name apps from the big companies all work well and I don't have complaints about them, but for some things it is really hard finding a decent app.  Luckily the Kindle Fire versions of apps are usually well done so given the choice I select those.Still, the negatives outweigh the positives and I would still be willing to pay twice as much for an iPad.  Were this a $100 device I'd give it a qualified recommendation, but Amazon markets it as an iPad killer, and that it ain't.

Reviews.Title: changed rating...and sad about that!!
Reviews.Author: AmazonFan
Reviews.Content: This is my fouth Kindle...yes, you read that right.  I had gotten the original Fire but found it bulky, heavy and the screen gave off too much glare.  I keep it charged, but seldom use and found myself going back to the prior generation for my reading (which is voracious).  This one "fits" me great.  Love the larger screen, but the device is very slender and easy to hold & store.  The display is simply spectacular and the streaming videos are spoiling me!  The speakers are really incredible for such a small gadget.  Easy to set up and I find the keyboard just fine and no inconvenience to check for battery.  To keep the cost lower I am happy to trade off a few things and for me, Amazon put the money where the bang is - speakers, display.  One thing is that I am not able to read my books as comfortably as one of the older Kindles with the non-glare surface.  In fairness, though, I have had cataract surgery so my eyes are rather sensistive doing close up things.  Love the case and the fact I can just close it and I'm done!Well done, Amazon.  It was worth the wait for me.UPDATE - Sadly, after awhile the browser kept shutting down and automatically putting the device in sleep mode when using WIFI.  This started pretty much right after I got it and thought I must have kept hitting the power button to put it in sleep. It got continually worse until I had to return it.

Reviews.Title: First tablet for me
Reviews.Author: Amazon Customer
Reviews.Content: Got this today and it is lovely.  Does not feel cheap and set-up was lightning fast.Things I like a lot:It gets better wi-fi reception than any other device in my place.The screen is lovely and the aspect ration is fantastic for watching HD videos.  There is barely any of the screen blocked out.Downton Abbey is free for Amazon Prime!  I have been happily watching episodes for the past 2 hours.App purchases are easy and so far everything I use is available in the app store.Games play wellThe sound is FANTASTIC.  My smartphone and laptop have Beats audio and the fire is actually better sounding over the speakers.Things I am still figuring out:Syncing of some things here and there.  I got the Epicurious app and cannot figure out how to send ingredient lists to my phone so I can pick up stuff while shopping.Some of my video files from my computer are not supported file formats.  Not the end of the world...but now I have to convert them.I still prefer the look of e-ink for books.  Kindle keyboard, you are still needed.The battery icon does not change when the device is charging and since I have cats that can turn off powerstrips it would be good if it let me know that is was charging successfully.

Reviews.Title: The Good, The Bad, and The Ugly
Reviews.Author: Christine in Long Beach
Reviews.Content: I just got my Kindle Fire 8.9 HD yesterday, so I plan to update the review as I get to know it better.It's my first tablet device and I am, so far, feeling pretty lukewarm.  Initially, I was reluctant to get an iPad because they are more expensive, can't use Flash, and I'm aready familiar with the MS and Android operating systems.  Of course, now Adobe that won't support flash for any tablets, that's a moot point.Visually, this Kindle is fantastic.  Good resolution, readable in different light and from different angles.  I give it high marks for that.  The battery life seems pretty good, but I've been spoiled by my Droid Razr Maxx and now have high standards.The one application I was really looking forward to, to be able to read the New Yorker on my Kindle, is completely buggy.  I spoke with a nice man at Amazon App customer service, and he told me that it's a known problem and the developer (Conde Nast) will need to fix it.  Bummer on that, but I'm hoping for a fix shortly.My biggest complaint is the location of the USB connection - bottom center if you're holding this in "landscape" mode.  I bought the leather cover, which works as a stand, so that we can watch movies, but with the Kindle plugged in, you can't use the stand!  That's CRAZY!  Who among us wouldn't want to keep it plugged in (unless you're in a plane) while watching a movie?  Otherwise, you've drained it completely.  The Kindle Fires from last year have the USB access on the short side - wayyyy more practical.The leather cover has its own issues, and I'll review those on the appropriate page.Interim verdict:  3 out of 5.  Good but not as great as I had hoped for.

Reviews.Title: Kindle Freezes
Reviews.Author: David White
Reviews.Content: I bought my Dad the Kindle Fire for his birthday and it froze constantly.  The replacement has been no better and freezes constantly, also.  If you google kindle freeze on the internet, this problem is all over the place and seems to be a common ailment.

Reviews.Title: Excellent!
Reviews.Author: lloyd a. pulliam
Reviews.Content: Bought this to replace the smaller Kindle my wife has. This is her Christmas present and need I say she couldn't wait till Christmas to start using it! She loves it!!! P.S. three weeks after I bought it Amazon came out with a $50 promotional discount on it. I called them yesterday and asked if they would give the discount to me even though I bought it before they offered it. No problem, they credited my Visa! Amazon you people are AWESOME!!!!!

Reviews.Title: Exactly what was advertised - very satisfied
Reviews.Author: Jeffrey Stanton
Reviews.Content: I ordered the Kindle Fire HD 8.9" from Amazon, along with some accessories, and all I can say, well done Amazon. Everything was delivered on time, well packaged and does exactly what it's suppose to do. This is a Christmas gift for my wife and I couldn't wait until Christmas, so I gave it to her today, the same day I received it. The Kindle Fire HD 8.9 was my choice after doing weeks worth of researching reviews and talking to friends. She absolutely loves it and that means everything to me. Just to see how excited she is as she learns about it is priceless. I have ordered other products from Amazon and have always been satisfied with the product and their service. I am so pleased and impressed with this Kindle and with Amazon. I would recommend both to everyone. Thank you again.

Reviews.Title: Wow
Reviews.Author: E. Henry "Crafty Jean"
Reviews.Content: Although I have a Nook basic book reader, I decided to purchase the Kindle Fire. The HD screen is awesome! It is easy to use by an older semi-techie like myself. I like the carousel of your current/favorite choices. Most of the time it will be used for books or games, but the ability to access other things is great!

Reviews.Title: It All Depends What You Need
Reviews.Author: A. Anderson "ann0314"
Reviews.Content: I have tried out a LOT of different services now , we have iPods (4) and a father with the upper end iPad, we have a cellphone and had a tablet that was Google/Android based, we own a Surface and now we own Kindles (3). Yes I know we jump around a lot LOL. That is because we are trying to find that good balance between features, affordability, longevity, customer service, and ease that meets our needs with the stress on affordability because we are a family of 4 and this technology moves so fast that by the time you buy xyz 3, the new 6 is coming out LOL and keeping up can get VERY pricey on a family budget. My review is about contrasting the differences from my perspective:Customer Service (10/10):In this category for me, Amazon and the Kindle win, hands down. EXCELLENT customer service and I don't mean or take that word lightly at all. I've had to call all 4 companies for things and by FAR Amazon has been the best to deal with. I truly commend them for that in a time where it seems that area lacks more and more.Stability and Speed (7/10):Here I think the iPad/iPods/iPhones win it. Having used all the varying systems by far I think the iPads are the most stable and quick. That said, since the other companies are playing catchup, I would expect that to be so. The Kindle to me falls not terribly behind though. It does freeze here and there and I have had to do a shutdown/restart on occasion, more then with the iPods/iPad, but it isn't to the frequency that I have had to with other products so for me it isn't far off pace.Ease of Use/Base System Features (6.5/10):If you are coming from an iWhatever, you are probably going to come up a bit irritated and possibly baffled and very well may not initially like the Kindle. I know initially when we got ours I was "underwhelmed" especially with how things are setup. In this aspect I think iPads and Android systems have a leg up especially if you are like me and are a bit of an organizational freak. There are NO folders here, no way to move around or order things "your way". To me this was probably the BIGGEST issue I had with the Kindle. If you are someone new to tablets and this is your first, I think the Kindle is pretty straight forward and easy enough to figure out quickly. I know my 11 year old was off and running with it almost instantly."Fun" Applications (9/10):In this area the Kindle is right in line with the rest. For a kid actually BETTER then the other three in terms of Parental Controls and services geared to keep your kids happy without the worry of your child using your credit card accidentally purchase to purchase something (though I will say I have less experience with this feature in the iPads so am speaking more about the Google and Microsoft systems for handling this which are both not so hot especially if you are a family with kids and adults using the same account or wishing to. On the application front, the worst of the bunch is the Surface which has a lot of NOTHING at the moment :( It is new so somewhat expected but I wasn't prepared for quite how anemic their selection really is. Probably one of the largest areas where the Surface falls very flat.Productivity (7/10):If you are looking for a tablet to Browse the net, I think iPad wins it. The Kindles and Android based tablets do well though for the casual user but for a power user you may find the Kindle a bit laggy. If you are looking for something to check e-mail the iPad, Androids, and Kindle all do well. The Surface though has a HUGE issue there. You have to use internet apps to check your e-mail if you have pop3 accounts...REALLY? O.o LOL If you are wanting to use MS Office products the the Surface wins. The rest do have apps that "work" but they do fall short in some areas so you wanna research if you choose this or one of the others to be sure there is something that does what you need. I will say if looking for something more for "school" for a child, the Surface, iPad, or Android tablets that run higher may be better. This system is good for general things listed above but not necessarily strong if you are looking for it to be a laptop replacement for heavy typing and taking notes etc. Great though for browsing forums, getting e-mail, internet, and light work.Reading (10/10):This is handled pretty well across the board with the availability of the Kindle app on most everything these days, though being able to borrow books if you are a Prime Member once a month or being able to restrict what your kids are reading is handled best by using the Physical Kindle.Movies, Music, and Sound (10/10):Strangely enough, the Kindle won on this level for me for a couple reasons (the Surface takes a good second because of the ability to add SD and flash cards to expand its size as do some of the Android systems) Amazon, unknown to me, has "tablet" editions of their movies...I LOVE THIS. If I buy a movie, Amazon gives you a full res version and a mobile version. If you DL the mobile version and put it on the tablet it takes up about 1/2 the space as the same movie on the other systems which means you can put double the movies on it. You do lose some resolution but if it's to keep kids busy on a long car ride its WONDERFUL. If you are more into the quality and want the HD etc though that is there still as an option as well. I also liked the Amazon Prime aspect in this area as well, giving access to lots of movies with your membership. Granted on this Kindle remember you have to have wifi to use Prime. On the music and sound side, I found the speakers on my Kindle to be by FAR the best of the group. The sound is actually REALLY nice. I have to admit I was impressed.Affordability (10/10):Definitely between the Kindles and the Google/Android units I think. For what you are getting for the price I think both these systems are doing a nice job. The iPad is great but not necessarily affordable for the average person especially when you consider what you have now will be outdated in a year or so (if you are lucky) if money is an issue, I would definitely consider these two systems though I won't say the Surface or iPads are unreasonable for what they do, just with their added features etc also have added cost. What that is worth to you really is a personal thing though :)To close (thank heavens right) after getting past the initial shock of how different this system was to the other 3 (especially the Apple system which OS wise I personally like most), I have really enjoyed it and would most definitely recommend it though whether it is best for you really does depend (as you can see above) what it is you are looking for. Fun, Affordability, For a Child, Productivity, Work etc. But for a general use Tablet for a child, reading, browsing the net without a laptop in your lap, I think this tablet definitely does it's job and very very nicely :) My whole family was happy with this purchase and I have recommended it to quite a few friends etc now especially those with kids or looking for an inexpensive solution to the Tablet quest.

Reviews.Title: I love my Kindle
Reviews.Author: Krystal
Reviews.Content: I'll be truthful, I love my Kindle.  I'm new to the tablet world and find it so easy to walk around and do anything i want with my Kindle in hand.  It gives me a whole new view on apps, reading books, watching movies (especially since i have Prime!) and looking at images.As I said, in love, however there are a few things that make me wonder why they didn't catch some bugs before shipping these out to customers.  They are the following:* The Web seems to never be able to successfully open a Webpage the first time when clicking through from an app.  It never fails to ask if i want to reopen my tab because the Web failed at opening it the first time.* My "Photo" option to take photos seems to always freeze.  It will then disable me from taking a photo.* I seem to have to "touch" on something more than once for it to decide to open.I have had my kindle for only 10 days, I think its a great tablet, but think it also could be improved.

Reviews.Title: The Kindle Audio Book Experience
Reviews.Author: Mylrea Estell "Lush Vineyard"
Reviews.Content: I received my Kindle Fire HD 8.9", Dolby Audio, Dual-Band Wi-Fi, 32 GB - Includes Special Offers about two weeks ago. There are plenty of reviews about the overall conformation and performance of the Kindle tablets, but very little about the audio book and Whispersync experience.  Amazon has a selection of free classic books for Kindle, each of which has a companion narration, also free, available from Audible. These are an excellent selection of performances by well know narrators, three of which I had previously purchased myself. I highly recommend new Kindle owners "buy" these free titles and their companion audios.  Whispersync works in multiple ways across multiple devises. I can read or listen to a book on my Kindle, then pick up where I left off, reading or listening using the Kindle app on my Android phone. I especially like the immersive reading function, where the text on the screen is subtly highlighted and "turns the page" following the simultaneous narration.  The immersive reading does not work with books borrowed from The Amazon Prime lending library or with Audible narrations and Kindle books borrowed from the public library, but is very effective when using purchased Kindle books. Audible titles are often deeply discounted when the Kindle book is purchased FIRST. Unfortunately if I want Kindle books to mate to my hundreds of previously purchased audio books, they must be bought at full price. Not a big deal for me as I mostly listen on the go, but no early-adopter wants to feel that they have missed out due to their patronage.  My sole disappointment in the devise has been with the speaker volume, particularly with regard to audio books. I find the maximum volume to be adequate for steaming video from Netflix or Amazon Prime video, but for some reason the audio books are much lower in volume, too quiet for my middle aged ears, even when the Kindle is set on full volume. The speaker capacity is clearly there, and the audiobook volume is fine when I use earphones with my MP3 player, phone or the Kindle, but I can barely hear audio books on the external speakers when holding my Kindle while alone in a quiet room.  My mother has macular degeneration, and audio books are important to her. I had hoped that she could use my Kindle, and the clear controls on its bright screen to access the library of Audible titles I have acquired. She simply could not hear the narrations. Of course she could use headphones, and I am considering Bluetooth speakers, but these extraneous devises are needlessly complex for an elderly person.  I wonder if a software update might allow higher volume audio book playback?  I would also like to see an Overdrive app for the Kindle so that I can use audio books from my state library system. I listen to about 100 audio books a year, most of them free from the library. That does not keep me from being a good Amazon/Audible customer. I have subscribed to Audible's one or two book credits per month program for nearly four years, and have bought more books at the reduced member rate. As long as I'm unable to use my Kindle to download library audio books, I need to use a parallel set of devises for most of my listening. I look forward to software which would allow me to integrate all of my reading and listening.  Since Amazon has purchased Audible and has made great strides to integrate the Kindle reading and listening experience, it is clear that they have identified this as part of the future of reading. Please Amazon programmers do something so that I can set my Kindle down in a room and listen to an audio book as I go about my business.

Reviews.Title: Major bugs never get resolved, quickly loses product software support (no updates).
Reviews.Author: Digitalmaster
Reviews.Content: I can't recommend this product because of the issues that I have had with it the past 4 months that I have owned it.First, when it comes to hardware, I would rate it 3/5. It loses two stars because the power button is on the side, right where the average user holds it to browse the web and play games. Because of the location of the button, it is constantly being depressed, putting it in sleep mode, and having to repeatedly unlock it during a game, or while browsing.The Silk browser is buggy, and I regularly have problems with it crashing. In all fairness, it could be the onscreen keyboard, as most all of my problems happen when the keyboard dialog comes up. Regardless, it makes this unusable for most things that I actually use this for.It is good for videos, and as an Amazon Prime subscriber, it is a great unit, but it spends more time on my shelf due to the issues mentioned above.It's a shame, because I really wanted to love this unit, and less than a month after purchasing, it was replaced with a new unit addressing some of the physical button problems that I mentioned above; problems Amazon told me that they had not heard from other customers... Despite the fact that they addressed the problem in the new version.As a regular Amazon customer, that is using their cloud service, prime, and owns a few Kindle's, this was my most disappointing purchase.

Reviews.Title: Not perfect, but still a great device
Reviews.Author: A. Rosario
Reviews.Content: I was debating between a Nexus 10 and the Kindle Fire HD.  Both devices have their advantages and disadvantages.The Nexus has the Google Play Store along with all of its apps, but you cannot access things such as Amazon Prime without using the browser.  Also, getting a Nexus 10 requires you to work with Google Play Store support which is not always the greatest as I have had to deal with and still am on an issue regarding a music purchase.The Kindle does not have access to the Google Play Store, but it does have the Amazon Appstore as well as Amazon Prime access.  The Amazon Appstore has most of the apps the Google Play Store has including Netflix and many of the games.  The biggest gripe I have with the Kindle is that for some reason Amazon does not offer any of the official Google apps such as Gmail, GTalk, Google Maps and Google Music.  There is a work around to get these apps on the device as I have installed them myself.  You have to authorize installation of 3rd party apps on the device and download the .apk file from a trusted website.  There are numerous websites out there that have official Google apps all you have to do is search for the .apk for the specific app.  Unfortunately, there is no support for the apps this way so you do not get updates and many times the icon looks blurry and not HD on the Kindle carousel.  Other than that, the Kindle is a great device especially when combined with Amazon Prime.  I am using a stylus with it now and find it works better with it.  The WIFI antennas are very good for the device and can connect to very weak signals with ease, would not recommend connecting to just any network as there are hackers out there looking to phish for anything.Amazon Prime is great as it not only grants you access to the numerous TV shows and movies Amazon has under contract, but it allows to borrow books for free from Amazon.As far as the price with the offers goes, I opted to include the offers as it knocked $15 off the price and the offers are only on the device when it is locked.  Upon waking the device (pressing the power button) an offer is displayed.  You swipe to unlock the device and the offer is gone, not to be seen again until you press the power button again once the device is off.  It is not bothersome at all.  I have not had any problems with the offers thing and at times I have been interested by the offers.I opted for the Kindle, purchased December of 2012, as it was cheaper and it allowed me to access Amazon Prime shows with no problem.  I also liked the Kindle reading aspect of it.  The device does have a setting under reading font, Sepia, which makes it so much easier to read than a regular white screen.  This is actually on any device that you download the Kindle app for including cell phones.I would recommend this device to anyone looking for a tablet that allows for a lot of media consumption as it has access to Amazon Prime with ease as well as Netflix.  In addition, it would be a better device for families as it allows parents to lock parts of the device to prevent children from purchasing or accessing things they are not supposed to.

Reviews.Title: This is by far the best tablet out there for the price!
Reviews.Author: Amazon Customer "Kevin Hearn"
Reviews.Content: Let me just start off by saying that I am not an apple fanboy, so I have never truly been impressed with iPads or any other Apple product after 2000. I don't feel like the value is there, and as someone who doesn't have a ton of cash to drop on something like a tablet, I just can't justify spending minimum $500-800 on one.I have had my Kindle Fire HD 8.9" tablet (32 GB) since they first came out in November and all I can say is: WOW! These tablets are amazing! I can tell you that it has literally changed my life (in a good way). :) I am going to list my comments individually in sections so y'all can see the parts that are most applicable to you.Build quality:I like the very solid, ergonomic feel of this Kindle. It is light enough to hold in one hand comfortably, yet I never feel like I'm going to drop it due to its weight (unlike my Galaxy S2 Smartphone). I do not, however, like the buttons on the top that control volume and the on/off. These buttons are almost completely flush to the device and it can be very difficult to press them. I also continually press the wrong button on the volume rocker to change the volume on the device because it feels backwards to me. I also wish the device could know when I changed it from landscape to portrait and adjust the volume knob to be a little more intuitive that way. That may sound like nitpicking, but it can be an annoyance.Screen:On that note, the screen on this thing is just gorgeous. I have used it outside, inside, full light, no light, everywhere you can imagine and I have never had a problem seeing anything on the device anywhere. I live in South Texas and it can be quite bright here in the daytime (especially around noon-2pm) and I have spent many Saturdays outside reading my Kindle without any problems. It does require more brightness out of the screen which reduces battery life, but I never read outside for more than two or three hours so I have never had an issue with running out of power. I cannot say enough positive things about this screen!User Interface:I love the Amazon Silk browser, it is great and works seamless with almost everything. I did the infamous flash workaround with the dolphin browser (google it) and that works great as well. The only complaint I have about the apps is...sometimes I don't want apps to come onto the carousel after I use them. I am major OCD and I like to have my carousel totally empty besides the book that I am reading. I like the apps and I use them often, but I have to remove them from the carousel periodically. I wish there was an option that said "do not put apps on carousel", or even a list of apps you could put on the device that would do the same. Again, nitpicky....but a tad bit annoying.Reading:What can I say about the reading on this device? It is superb. From magazines, to books, to newspapers...everything is great. I have never had a problem with any of this and it works great. I love getting my Men's Fitness and my fiance loves getting Cosmo as well. They are always crisp and clear (gotta love that HD screen) and are never glitchy or freezing. This is really where this Kindle has changed my life. I am a teacher and it is very difficult for me to fit certain books into my backpack for school...but it is easy to fit my Kindle in there. I have read more books in the past five months of owning this thing than I had in a year.Ordering:Part of the reason I have had so much success with my reading is that it is very easy to order books from the device. I have bought books and had family members buy me books for my birthday and never had a problem. It is almost TOO easy to buy things for this device...because I spend a lot of money on books to read every month. Again, no complaints. It is far easier to make a buy on my device (which I keep with me perpetually) instead of having to remember to hit up a bookstore on the way home. And, let me add, cheaper to buy on the Kindle.Videos:I bought extra storage space to put my DVR shows on my Kindle for watching at various points when I am not home. Besides the fact that the only content it plays is .MP4 (a tad annoying) but the videos are always crisp and clear and never have to buffer or queue. I have absolutely zero complaints about video or playback on the device.Overall I would say that I have absolutely zero regrets with my Kindle. I have nitpicky concerns, but they are far outweighed by the benefits of this device. If you are like me and looking for something to make reading books and magazines easier-or even watching videos or movies, this is definitely the Kindle for you. I hope this review helps any of you that are on the fence about buying a Kindle Fire HD 8.9". I love it so much, in fact, my fiance is getting one for her birthday, so she stops stealing mine. :)

Reviews.Title: My third version of the kindle
Reviews.Author: W. Dietrich "WD"
Reviews.Content: I have had all 3 versions of the kindle from the original which was just a reader with no color ink (which i really enjoyed) to the 2011 kindle fire to the new Kindle Fird HD 8.9.I am giving the 8.9 4 stars for one reason when I flip the kindle sideways when reading a book I get two pages at once instead of one page which is what I get if I am holding the kindle up right.  There may be a way to fix this but I am not sure how.  They say the new Kindle Fire HD has a sharper picture than the original Kindle Fire but for my eyesight I can not tell the difference.  What I do like is the size is awsome and makes playing games like angry birds or fruit ninja even better.  The backlight for reading makes reading with the lights off a breeze (does not hurt my eyes at all).
